revision.text:
{{pp-30-500|small=yes}} {{Very long|date=March 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Gaza blockade}} '''Reactions to the Gaza flotilla raid''' on 31 May 2010 ranged from fierce condemnation to strong support for Israel.
Israel expressed regret over loss of life in the [[Gaza flotilla raid]], yet stated that the operation was a "clear case of self defense".<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.pmo.gov.il/PMOEng/Communication/Spokesman/2010/06/spokehatshara010610.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605042336/http://www.pmo.gov.il/PMOEng/Communication/Spokesman/2010/06/spokehatshara010610.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date= 5 June 2010 |title=Statement by PM Netanyahu Regarding Flotilla to Gaza |publisher=Prime Minister's Office, Israel |date=1 June 2010 |accessdate=2 June 2010 |df= }}</ref> Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologised for the incident in March 2013, which he said was necessitated by the [[Syrian civil war]].<ref>{{cite news |author=Herb Keinon |date=24 March 2013 |title='Syria crisis necessitated Turkey apology' |newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |url=http://www.jpost.com/Diplomacy-and-Politics/Syria-crisis-necessitated-Turkey-apology-307535}}</ref> The incident also drew attention to the blockade of the Gaza Strip, which was condemned.<ref name="NYT Gaza-Bound">{{cite news|last=Bronner|first=Ethan|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|title=Israeli Military Boards Gaza-Bound Aid Ship|date=5 June 2010|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/06/world/middleeast/06flotilla.html|accessdate=5 June 2010}}</ref> [[Secretary-General of the United Nations]] [[Ban Ki-moon]] called for a full investigation and urged Israel to provide a full explanation. Many countries called for an international investigation and civilian protests erupted around the world. Four countries downgraded their diplomatic relations with Israel and/or withdrew ambassadors: Ecuador, Nicaragua, [[South Africa–Israel relations|South Africa]], and [[Turkey–Israel relations|Turkey]]. Twelve Latin American countries condemned Israeli actions: [[Argentina–Israel relations|Argentina]],<ref>[http://english.telam.com.ar/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=9361:argentina-condemns-israeli-attack-to-gaza-humanitarian-flotilla-&catid=36:foreign-affairs "Argentina condemns Israeli attack to Gaza humanitarian flotilla"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706082637/http://english.telam.com.ar/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=9361%3Aargentina-condemns-israeli-attack-to-gaza-humanitarian-flotilla-&catid=36%3Aforeign-affairs |date= 6 July 2011 }}, [[Télam]]</ref> Bolivia,<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/news/bolivia-cuts-ties-with-israel-seeks-genocide-charges-against-israeli-officials-1.268131 "Bolivia cuts ties with Israel, seeks genocide charges against Israeli officials"], ''[[Haaretz]]''</ref> Brazil,<ref>[https://archive.is/20120724072242/http://www.brazil.gov.br/news/history/2010/05/31/israeli-raid-on-the-201cfreedom-flotilla/newsitem_view?set_language=en "Brazil vehemently condemns the Israeli action..."]</ref> [[Chile–Israel relations|Chile]], Cuba, Ecuador, Mexico, Nicaragua, Paraguay, [[Peru–Israel relations|Peru]], [[Uruguay–Israel relations|Uruguay]] and [[Venezuela–Israel relations|Venezuela]]. Israel had developed significant bilateral relationships with seven of them. Twenty-three European countries condemned or protested Israeli actions: [[Albania–Israel relations|Albania]], [[Azerbaijan–Israel relations|Azerbaijan]], [[Belarus–Israel relations|Belarus]], Bosnia and Herzegovina, [[Bulgaria–Israel relations|Bulgaria]], [[Croatia–Israel relations|Croatia]], the [[Czech Republic–Israel relations|Czech Republic]], [[Estonia–Israel relations|Estonia]], [[Finland–Israel relations|Finland]], [[France–Israel relations|France]], [[Greece–Israel relations|Greece]], Iceland, [[Ireland–Israel relations|Ireland]], Italy, Luxembourg, [[Norway–Israel relations|Norway]], Portugal, [[Israel-Romania relations|Romania]], [[Russia–Israel relations|Russia]], [[Israel-Serbia relations|Serbia]], [[Spain–Israel relations|Spain]], Sweden and the [[United Kingdom–Israel relations|United Kingdom]]. Israel was widely condemned in the [[Arab world]]. Thirteen non-Arab Asian countries condemned Israeli actions: Brunei, [[China–Israel relations|China]], [[India–Israel relations|India]], [[Indonesia–Israel relations|Indonesia]], [[Iran–Israel relations|Iran]], [[Japan–Israel relations|Japan]], Malaysia, Maldives, [[North Korea–Israel relations|North Korea]], [[Pakistan–Israel relations|Pakistan]], Sri Lanka, Turkey and Uzbekistan. Israel was also condemned by: [[Australia–Israel relations|Australia]], Kenya, [[New Zealand–Israel relations|New Zealand]]<ref name="NZ_Herald_10649092">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10649092 |title=NZ adds to chorus of outrage at raid deaths |author=Young, Audrey |date=2 June 2010 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=4 November 2011}}</ref> and [[South Africa–Israel relations|South Africa]]. Eighteen countries expressed regret over the loss of life: Israel, Argentina, Azerbaijan, Bangladesh, Canada, Czech Republic, Croatia, Egypt, Estonia, Greece, [[Holy See–Israel relations|Holy See]], India, Ireland, Japan, Sri Lanka, the United Kingdom, the United States and Uruguay.{{Citation needed|date=August 2010}} Unofficial responses included civilian protests against Israeli action following reports of the deaths aboard the ''[[MV Mavi Marmara]]''.
The Turkish government and the İHH were also criticised. Several journalists accused Turkey of aligning itself with Iran, Syria, Hamas and Hezbollah, and expressed concern over the contribution of [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] and his government to fueling public rage.<ref>{{cite news |last=Benhorin |first=Yitzhak |title=Criticism in Turkey: Erdogan knew Gaza sail would be violent |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/Ext/Comp/ArticleLayout/CdaArticlePrintPreview/1,2506,L-3902451,00.html |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=9 June 2010 |accessdate=19 June 2010}}</ref> Pro-Israeli rallies took place in Los Angeles, Miami, Vienna, Great Britain, Brussels and Israel.<ref name="jpost.com">{{cite news |last=Liel |first=Alon |url=http://www.jpost.com/JewishWorld/JewishNews/Article.aspx?id=177627 |title=Pro-Israel rallies planned worldwide |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=20 March 2011 |accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="miamiherald.com">[http://www.miamiherald.com/2010/06/06/1667096/hundreds-join-to-back-israel.html "Hundreds in Miami rally in support of Israel"]. ''[[Miami Herald]]''</ref>
== Supranational organizations ==<!--all the bodies in this list are "inter-governmental AND international--> <!--WP:FLAGCRUFT-->
=== {{Flag|United Nations}} === *The Secretary-General of the United Nations, [[Ban Ki-moon]] condemned the violence,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/meast/05/31/israel.gaza.raid.reaction/index.html |title=World reaction to Israel after raid on aid flotilla mostly negative |publisher=[[CNN]] |date= 31 May 2010|accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> called for "a full investigation to determine exactly how this bloodshed took place" and urged Israel to "provide a full explanation [into the matter]".<ref name="alj-blog">{{cite news |last=Carlstrom|first=Gregg|title=Aftermath of Israel's attack on Gaza flotilla |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=31 May 2010 |url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2010/05/31/aftermath-israels-attack-gaza-flotilla |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120525025130/http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2010/05/31/aftermath-israels-attack-gaza-flotilla |dead-url=yes |archive-date=25 May 2012 |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> He also said that the underlying problem behind the raid was the siege of Gaza, which he described as "counter-productive, unsustainable and wrong".<ref>[http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=128837&sectionid=351020202 "UN demands Israel lift siege of Gaza"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100603032549/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=128837&sectionid=351020202 |date= 3 June 2010 }}. [[Press TV]] (2 June 2010).</ref> On 2 August he announced that a U.N. panel was to investigate, see [[Gaza flotilla raid#United Nations investigation|Gaza flotilla raid]].
<!--Info on the result of int'l action at the bottom. Duplicated info. removed--> *United Nations [[High Commissioner for Human Rights]] [[Navanethem Pillay]] said "I am also registering my shock at reports that humanitarian aid was met with violence early this morning, reportedly causing death and injury as the convoy approached the Gaza coast."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.expatica.com/ch/news/swiss-news/un-rights-chief-shocked-at-gaza-aid-flotilla-violence_72267.html |title=UN rights chief shocked at Gaza aid flotilla massacre |publisher=[[Expatica]] |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref> *The UN Special Coordinator for the Middle East Peace Process, [[Robert Serry]], and the director of the [[United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East]], [[Filippo Grandi]] declared "these tragedies are completely inevitable if Israel does not listen to the callings of the international community to end the unacceptable and counter-productive blockade of Gaza."<ref>[http://www.emol.com/noticias/internacional/detalle/detallenoticias.asp?idnoticia=416123 "La ONU condena el asalto israelí a la flota humanitaria en Gaza"], ''[[El Mercurio]]''.</ref> *[[File:UNRWA-logo.jpg|25px]] [[United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East|The Relief and Works Agency]] also said "we are shocked by reports of killings and injuries of people on board boats carrying supplies for Gaza, apparently in international waters. Such tragedies are entirely avoidable if Israel heeds the repeated calls of the international community to end its counterproductive and unacceptable blockade of Gaza.<ref name="aljaz">{{cite news |date=3 June 2010 |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2010/05/20105316216182630.html |title=Global outrage over Israeli attack |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref>
===Others=== '''[[African Union]]''' (''See [[Reactions to the Gaza flotilla raid#Africa|below]]'').
'''{{Flag|Arab League}}''' (''See [[Reactions to the Gaza flotilla raid#Arab League|below]]'').
''' [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations]]''' condemned the Israeli attack, called on Israel to lift its blockade of Gaza, expressed solidarity with Turkey, and urged the UN to conduct an investigation.<ref>[http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/1060331/1/.html "ASEAN, Gulf ministers condemn Israeli raid on flotilla"], [[Channel NewsAsia]], 1 June 2010.</ref>
'''{{Flag|European Union}}''' (''See [[Reactions to the Gaza flotilla raid#Europe|below]]'').
'''{{Flagu|NATO}}''' held an emergency meeting on 1 June 2010 in response to the attack.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=128532&sectionid=351020202 |title=NATO to hold meeting on Israeli attack |publisher=[[Press TV]] |accessdate=2 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100603212149/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=128532&sectionid=351020202 |archivedate= 3 June 2010 |df= }}</ref> Turkey is a NATO signatory, and Article 5 of the NATO charter states that armed attacks against one or more NATO members in Europe or North America will be considered an attack against all of them, and each will take action (including the possibility of armed force) "to restore and maintain the security of the North Atlantic area". Article 6 explicitly mentions the Mediterranean Sea as a location for where attacks will trigger responses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/official_texts_17120.htm |title=Official text: The North Atlantic Treaty, 04-Apr.-1949 |publisher=NATO |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> The result of the meeting was that the NATO Secretary General issued a statement expressing "deep regret" over the loss of lives and "As a matter of urgency, [he] also request[ed] the immediate release of the detained civilians and ships held by Israel."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/news_63983.htm?mode=pressrelease |title=Statement by the Secretary General of NATO on Israeli operation against ships bound for Gaza |date= 1 June 2010 |publisher=NATO |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref>
'''{{Flag|Organization of American States}}''' (''See [[Reactions to the Gaza flotilla raid#Americas|below]]'').
'''{{Flag|Organisation of Islamic Cooperation}}''' Secretary General [[Ekmeleddin İhsanoğlu]] condemned Israel for the attack on the people on the ship.<ref>[http://www.oic-oci.org/topic_detail.asp?t_id=3833 "OIC Secretary General: Israeli Aggression on the Relief Convoy Heading for Gaza is a Crime and Blatant Violation of All International Laws Norms and Standards"]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The '''[[Southeast European Cooperation Process]]''', at a meeting of the 13 member countries in June 2010, condemned Israel's raid and demanded an impartial, independent and internationally credible investigation.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]] |title=Balkan summit condemns Israeli raid on Gaza flotilla|date=23 June 2010|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/balkan-summit-condemns-israeli-raid-on-gaza-flotilla-1.297909 |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |accessdate=23 June 2010}}</ref>
'''[[File:Emblem of the ICRC.svg|border|25px]] [[International Committee of the Red Cross]]''' said that Israel's blockade violated the [[Geneva Conventions]] and stated that it constituted a collective punishment imposed in clear violation of Israel's obligations under international humanitarian law.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kershner|first1=Isabel|last2=Akram|first2=Fares|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|title=Israel Backs Panel to Examine Raid|date=13 June 2010|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/14/world/middleeast/14mideast.html|accessdate=16 June 2010}}</ref><ref>OHCHR: [http://www.icrc.org/web/eng/siteeng0.nsf/htmlall/palestine-update-140610 Gaza closure: not another year! ICRC 14 June 2010 News release 10/103]</ref>
==National reactions== {{Main article|National reactions to the Gaza flotilla raid}}
==Non-governmental organizations==
=== International Human Rights and advocacy organizations === * [[Amnesty International]] accused Israel of using excessive force, and claimed that the level of lethal force used was out of proportion to any threat that could have been posed by the activists. Amnesty International called on Israel to make public the rules of engagement used by the commandos, and to launch an "immediate, credible and independent investigation".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/israeli-killings-gaza-ship-activists-must-be-investigated-2010-05-31 |title=Israeli killings of Gaza ship activists must be investigated |publisher=[[Amnesty International]] |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> Amnesty International also called for an international inquiry, and called on Israel to invite UN experts to examine the incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/israeli-authorities-urged-commission-international-inquiry-2010-06-10 |title=Working to Protect Human Rights |publisher=[[Amnesty International]] |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> * The [[Foreign Press Association]], which represents hundreds of journalists in Israel and the Palestinian territories, has complained the Israeli military seized video and equipment from dozens of reporters on board the main ship. The FPA says the military is now selectively using footage to bolster its claims that commandos opened fire only after being attacked. FPA also criticized Israel's use of captured material without permission.<ref>{{cite news |author=Amy Teibel |date=4 June 2010 |publisher=Associated Press |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5ioi_0jtO9RjMwPNRoXNCndRPRq3gD9G3RA283 |title=Israel's use of captured video draws criticism |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100606040028/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5ioi_0jtO9RjMwPNRoXNCndRPRq3gD9G3RA283|archivedate=6 June 2010}}</ref> * [[Human Rights Watch]] called for a "full, impartial investigation" into the incident, and for the international community to make sure that any inquiries meet basic international standards, and that any wrongdoers were brought to justice. Human Rights Watch also called on Israel to grant all detained and injured flotilla members immediate access to legal counsel and their families, and to disclose the identities of all those injured and killed.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2010/05/31/israel-full-impartial-investigation-flotilla-killings-essential |title=Israel: Full, Impartial Investigation of Flotilla Killings Essential |publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]] |date=31 May 2010 |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> * [[Reporters Without Borders]] called for the release of the names of all journalists held after the raid. They said there were at least 15 foreign journalists in the convoy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/israel-israeli-military-prevents-media-31-05-2010,37630.html |publisher=[[Reporters Without Borders]] |title=Communication severed with flotilla media |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> A statement said "We deplore this assault, which left a heavy toll of dead and wounded. The journalists who were on the flotilla to cover the humanitarian operation were put in harm's way by this disproportionate reaction. We urge the Israeli authorities to release the detained journalists and allow them unrestricted access to the Gaza Strip. The international community needs accurate information about this Palestinian Territory.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=288991|title=RSF condemns flotilla censorship |publisher=[[Ma'an News Agency]] |accessdate=5 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120915021901/http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=288991 |archivedate=15 September 2012 }}</ref> * [[Stop the War Coalition]] issued a statement saying "The action should see Israel condemned under international law. Israel has repeatedly flouted law and public opinion worldwide in its treatment of the Palestinians. The decision by Israel to attack the flotilla with such loss of human life shows it is arrogant and deadly intent in opposing any aid to the Palestinians."<ref name="aljaz"/> * The President of the Algerian [[Movement of Society for Peace|MSP]] [[Bouguerra Soltani]], whose wife is part of the delegation, announced the dispatch of a parliamentary delegation to Turkey to try to get information about the 32 Algerians aboard the convoy.<ref>[http://www.ennaharonline.com/en/news/4038.html "Flotilla to Ghaza: Arab anger against Israel"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726023137/http://www.ennaharonline.com/en/news/4038.html# |date=26 July 2011 }}, Ennahar Online, 1 June 2010</ref> In an interview with Al-Aqsa TV, Imam Ahmad Ibrahimi, the Coordinator of Algerian Delegation to Flotilla, stated (as translated by [[MEMRI]]), "we felt no fear whatsoever of those brothers of apes and pigs. By Allah, I loathed them before, and my hatred of them has only grown, not because they punished and humiliated us, but because I had thought them to be worthy enemies, but it turns out that they are too despicable even to be called our enemies, because they are not our equals. They are cowards ... Our hatred for these people is so intense that we wished, at those moments, that we could have been bombs, and blow up among those brothers of apes and pigs."<ref>[http://www.memritv.org/clip_transcript/en/2504.htm "MEMRI Flotilla Coverage: Imam Ahmad Ibrahimi, Coordinator of Algerian Delegation to 'Freedom Flotilla': Our Hatred of Them Is So Intense That We Wished We Could Have Been Bombs and Blown Ourselves Up among the Brothers of Apes and Pigs"], [[Middle East Media Research Institute]], Clip 2504, 4 June 2010.</ref>
=== Israeli and Jewish organizations === The [[Australian Jewish Democratic Society]] said, "Unless the Israeli government can convincingly back up its claims that the Gaza aid convoy was not a project for delivering humanitarian aid to Gaza, but in reality a front for violent action, it invites the condemnation of everyone who supports negotiated conflict resolution and reinforces the view that Israel's professed support for human rights is a sham."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ajds.org.au/node/256 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605192452/http://ajds.org.au/node/256 |dead-url=yes |archive-date= 5 June 2010 |title=AJDS Statement on Israeli action against the Gaza Convoy |publisher=Australian Jewish Democratic Society |date= |accessdate=2 June 2010 |df= }}</ref>
[[B'Tselem]] demanded that an independent and effective investigation conducted by non-military officials be launched immediately. B'Tselem stated that among the issues that needed investigating are whether proportionate force was used, whether the soldiers were trained and equipped to cope with this type of event, what open-fire regulations were given to soldiers, and whether alternative options were considered.<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.btselem.org/English/Press_Releases/20100531.asp |date=31 May 2010 |title=Open an immediate investigation into the action to gain control of the flotilla to Gaza |publisher=[[B'Tselem]] |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref>
[[Jews for Justice for Palestinians]] said, "Jews For Justice For Palestinians (the largest alternative voice of Jews in the UK or Europe) utterly condemns Israel's aggressive military interception of the peaceful Free Gaza aid flotilla. We hold Israel responsible for the tragic deaths and injuries which this action caused."<ref>[http://jfjfp.com/?p=13408 "JfJfP statement on the flotilla interception"] [[Jews for Justice for Palestinians]]. Retrieved 19 June 2010.</ref>
German Jewish group [[Jewish Voices for a Just Peace]] decided to send a boat with school supplies and humanitarian aid to break the [[Gaza blockade]]. Kate Katzenstein-Leiterer, a leader of the group, said instead that they wanted to help preserve the State of Israel by showing that its current policies were wrong.<ref>{{cite news |author=DPA |title=Organizer of German Jewish Flotilla: We Aren't Betraying Israel |date=17 June 2010 |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |url=http://www.haaretz.com/jewish-world/organizer-of-german-jewish-flotilla-we-aren-t-betraying-israel-1.296724}}</ref> Due to excessive interest, the group subsequently decided to arrange a second vessel.<ref name="German Jews Inundated">{{cite news |agency=Deutsche Presse Agentur|title=German Jews 'inundated' with requests to join new Gaza aid flotilla |date=14 June 2010 |url=http://www.haaretz.com/jewish/german-jews-inundated-with-requests-to-join-new-gaza-aid-flotilla-1.296146 |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |accessdate=16 June 2010}}</ref>
Rabbi Dovid Feldman of [[Neturei Karta]] said: "Authentic [[Orthodox Jew]]ry worldwide decries unequivocally the cold-blooded slaughter carried out by the Zionist occupational forces against innocent, peaceful and freedom-loving noble activists committed to peace and human rights. This brutal attack took place in international waters on ships bearing humanitarian aid for our brethren, the Palestinian residents in the besieged Gaza Strip. It was an explicitly illegal act which breaches, in a serious manner, basic G-dly human rights, justice and law. This kind of behavior is, unfortunately, only to be expected from the Zionists. Their state's entire existence was built from the very start on Heresy, robbery and murder. They oppressed, murdered and expelled an entire people from its land." Adding, "We find it imperative to clearly declare that the State of 'Israel' does not represent the Jewish people, and certainly not the Jewish religion. They have no right to speak in our name, nor in the name of the holy Torah. They profane the Holy Land with their abominations, slaughters and countless other actions that emanate from this illegitimate State. Furthermore, the actual existence of this State is illegitimate as the holy Torah strictly and explicitly forbids any Jewish rule over the Holy Land." Neturei Karta protests took place in Ottawa, Montral, Washington, D.C., New York City, Jerusalem and London. Neturei Karta Rabbis visited the injured in Turkey.<ref>[http://www.nkusa.org/activities/Press/20100603Flotilla.cfm "Neturei Karta Condemns Israeli Attack on Flotilla"]. [[Neturei Karta]]. Retrieved on 2010-06-19.</ref>
=== Commercial organisations ===
* The [[International Chamber of Shipping]] (ICS), an association that represents 75 percent of the world's merchant fleet, has expressed "deep concern" over the boarding by Israeli forces in international waters. "The fundamental principles of international law, safe passage and freedom of navigation in international waters, must always be upheld by all of the world's nations," the organization said.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[Reuters]] |last=Saul|first=Jonathan|title=Q&A: Is Israel's naval blockade of Gaza legal?|date=3 June 2010|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE65133D20100602|accessdate=3 June 2010}}</ref>
=== Religious leaders === *Imam [[Fethullah Gülen]], a U.S.-based Turkish cleric, criticized the flotilla for trying to deliver aid without Israel's consent. He said the organizers' failure to seek accord with Israel before attempting to deliver aid "is a sign of defying authority, and will not lead to fruitful matters.... What I saw was not pretty. It was ugly."<ref name="gulen">{{cite news|title=Reclusive Turkish Imam Criticizes Gaza Flotilla|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704025304575284721280274694?mod=rss_Today's_Most_Popular|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | first=Joe | last=Lauria | date=4 June 2010}}</ref> * David Hatchwell Altaras, vice president of the 10,000 member Jewish community in Madrid, criticized the Spanish government's "knee-jerk" reaction to slam Israel's seizure of the Gaza flotilla. He added that the Spanish government "should be more even-handed and take more distance ... the IHH activists attacked Israeli forces in order to have a specific outcome."<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/JewishWorld/JewishNews/Article.aspx?id=178676 "Spanish Jewish leader promotes solidarity with Israel"], ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'', 17 June 2010</ref>
==Media== {{Main article|Media reactions to the Gaza flotilla raid}}
== Public opinion and political activism == ===Critical===<!--temporary re-addition because it make redundant "demonstrations" as a subject for section + sub-section--> [[File:Tv31052010.jpg|250px|thumb|One of the earliest Israeli demonstrations (31 May 2010). Demonstrators in front of Israeli Defence Ministry protest against IDF actions toward "Flotilla". Signs read in Hebrew "IDF-terror in uniform" and "Israel-state of terror".]]
Throughout 31 May, demonstrators gathered in the Middle East, Europe, North America and South Asia following the attack.<ref name="Gaza ship deaths: protests erupt around the world after deadly raid"/>
In Turkey, more than ten thousand people gathered to protest in [[Taksim Square]] in central [[Istanbul]] on the night of 31 May 2010.<ref name="Gaza ship deaths: protests erupt around the world after deadly raid">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/7790916/Gaza-ship-deaths-protests-erupt-around-the-world-after-deadly-raid.html|title=Gaza ship deaths: protests erupt around the world after deadly raid|date=31 May 2010 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |location=London |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> Hundreds of protesters then tried to storm the Israeli consulate in Istanbul. A second day of protests took place across Turkey; protestors marched in front of [[Istanbul]]'s Israeli consulate, and several people were arrested in [[Ankara]] after encountering police in front of the Israeli Embassy there.<ref>{{cite news |author=Marquez, Miguel |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/turks-protest-israel-gaza-flotilla-sinking/story?id=10793857 |title=Anger Against Israel Grows in Turkey: Protesters Gather Outside Israeli Embassy to Encourage Return of Turkish Citizens |date=1 June 2010 |publisher=[[ABC News]] |accessdate=1 June 2010}}</ref> On 1 June, Azerbaijani protesters gathered outside the [[Azerbaijan–Turkey relations|Turkish embassy]] in [[Baku]] to condemn the Israeli attack. The protesters were carrying the [[Azerbaijani flag|Azerbaijani]] and [[Turkish flag]]s. They also carried placards saying "Israel is a barbarian" and "Israel is a murderer," and chanted slogans such as "Azerbaijan and Turkey: one nation, two states", "Turkey's grief is Azerbaijan's grief" and "Down with Israel". The protesters stated their support for the Turkish government and people.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.azernews.az/site/shownews.php?news_id=21041 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706131029/http://www.azernews.az/site/shownews.php?news_id=21041 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 July 2011 |title=Azerbaijani protesters gathered in Baku |publisher=Azernews.az |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref>
In [[Tel Aviv]], [[leftist]] and [[rightist]] demonstrators clashed on 5 June 2010, as more than 6,000 citizens gathered to protest the Israeli raid against the aid convoy.<ref>{{cite news|last=Levinson|first=Chaim|newspaper=[[Haaretz]]|title=Leftist and rightist Israelis clash at Gaza flotilla protest in Tel Aviv|date=5 June 2010|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/leftist-and-rightist-israelis-clash-at-gaza-flotilla-protest-in-tel-aviv-1.294359|accessdate=5 June 2010}}</ref>
During a demonstration at a checkpoint between Israel and the [[West Bank]], which involved stone-throwing by Palestinian youths, Israeli soldiers fired tear gas canisters at demonstrators. An art student from New York, who according to a witness was not involved in any violence, lost an eye when one of the canisters fractured parts of her skull.<ref>{{Cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hkRx0N5aDIQc9V-dua0zuHm1JoqwD9G2P00O0|title=American hit in anti-Israeli protest loses eye|date=2 June 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qD0seROL?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hkRx0N5aDIQc9V-dua0zuHm1JoqwD9G2P00O0|archivedate=3 June 2010}}<br>{{cite news |publisher=[[Palestine Monitor]]|date=3 June 2010|url=http://www.palestinemonitor.org/spip/spip.php?article1431|title=Artist Loses Eye as Israeli Border Police Intentionally Target Demonstrators}}<br>{{cite news |publisher=[[Salon (website)|Salon]] |url=http://www.salon.com/news/politics/war_room/2010/06/02/emily_henochowicz_israel_shot|date=2 June 2010|title=American student loses eye in protest in Israel}}<br>{{cite news|url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/03/three-american-subplots-in-flotilla-drama/|title=Three American Subplots in Flotilla Drama|author=Robert Mackey|publisher=[[The New York Times]] blog|date=3 June 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qDfxjM8Y?url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/03/three-american-subplots-in-flotilla-drama/|archivedate=3 June 2010}}</ref>
In the [[Arab world]], thousands marched in condemnation on the streets of [[Baghdad]].<ref name="Thousands protest flotilla deaths, clashes in Athens"/> Thousands of Egyptians also rallied to request that [[Cairo]]'s Israeli ambassador be expelled and that the government open the Gaza border.<ref name="Thousands protest flotilla deaths, clashes in Athens"/> There were also demonstrations in [[Damascus]], [[Amman]], and [[Beirut]]. While Palestinians in the [[West Bank]] clashed with Israeli security forces who responded with tear gas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2010/05/201053116143622331.html |title=Turks march against Israeli attack – Europe |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> Several hundred [[Arab-Israelis|Arab protestors in Israel]] were arrested in [[Umm al-Fahm]] as the demonstrations turned violent. Protests were also held in the Arab cities of Acre, [[Sakhnin]], [[Arabe]] and [[Shfaram]], although there was no violence reported. A spontaneous demonstration also took place in [[Nazareth]] as Israeli security forces prepared to face an anticipated wave of violence.<ref>{{cite news |last=Khoury |first=Jack |url=http://www.haaretz.com/several-israeli-arab-protesters-arrested-in-mass-rallies-over-gaza-flotilla-deaths-1.293199 |title=Several Israeli Arab protesters arrested in mass rallies over Gaza flotilla deaths |work=[[Haaretz]] |location=Israel |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> Demonstration were also held in [[Sana'a]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2010}}<!--seen on TV, need online source-->
On 1 June 2010, in Malaysia, a man performed a personal protest before the United States embassy at [[Jalan Tun Razak]] when he "slashed himself with a penknife on the thighs and chest" to express his disapproval of the Israeli attack. He was bundled away to a hospital before the knife reached his neck.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Habibu, Siru |author2=Chiew, Steven |lastauthoramp=yes |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2010/6/1/nation/20100601120226&sec=nation |title=Man slashes himself in front of US embassy over Israeli raid |date=1 June 2010 |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |accessdate=1 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100603065106/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2010%2F6%2F1%2Fnation%2F20100601120226&sec=nation |archivedate=3 June 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Protests were held across Pakistan by journalists, political parties, and college students. The Lahore Press Club called for the release of all detained persons, and called the raid an "act of terrorism". They accused Israel of violating international law, and demanded an urgent explanation of the matter. They also demanded the Pakistani government to secure the release of the Pakistanis arrested.<ref name="Daily times">{{cite news|title=Journalists, civil society protest against Israel|url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2010\06\01\story_1-6-2010_pg13_2 |newspaper=Daily Times|date=1 June 2010 |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> Protests were also held in [[Jakarta]] and other cities across Indonesia.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2010/06/2010618503229683.html |title=Global rallies continue over Israel |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=1 June 2010 |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> Demonstrations were being organised in New Delhi and other Indian cities to condemn the action.<ref>[http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report_india-not-convinced-by-israel-s-action_1390814 "India not convinced by Israel's action"]. ''[[Daily News and Analysis]]'' (2010-06-02). Retrieved on 2010-06-19.</ref>
In Greece, thousands of protesters marched on the Israeli Embassy in [[Athens]], sparking clashes with police, the deployment of tear gas, five arrests and many injuries.<ref name="Thousands protest flotilla deaths, clashes in Athens">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE64U4SN20100531|title=Thousands protest flotilla deaths, clashes in Athens|date=31 May 2010 |publisher=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> Tear gas was also used in Paris to disperse the thousands of people who waved Palestinian and Turkish flags beside the Israeli Embassy.<ref name="Thousands protest flotilla deaths, clashes in Athens"/> Twenty-one cities in Sweden, including [[Gothenburg]] and [[Malmö]], held demonstrations, with thousands of protesters clutching Palestinian flags as they marched on the Israeli Embassy in [[Stockholm]], while speakers expressed their "disgust and dismay".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-06/01/c_13326095.htm|title=Massive protests in Sweden to condemn Israel for attacking Gaza aid flotilla|date=31 May 2010 |publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> In Norway, approximately 2,000 demonstrators gathered peacefully in front of the Israeli Embassy in [[Oslo]], while chanting slogans and calling for a "boycott of Israel" and closure of the Israeli Embassy.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dagbladet.no/2010/05/31/nyheter/utenriks/gaza/israel/demonstrasjon/11945135/|title=Up to 2,000 people demonstrated against Israel in Oslo|date=31 May 2010 |work=[[Dagbladet]] |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> In Italy, there were protests in many cities, including Rome, where one speaker said the situation was ''[[The Irish Times]]'' – Tuesday, 1 June 2010</ref> Protests took place across Ireland on 31 May, including [[Belfast]], [[Cork (city)|Cork]], Derry, [[Galway]], [[Sligo]] and [[Waterford]], while hundreds of protesters in [[Dublin]] marched from the Israeli embassy to the nearby US Embassy before returning to the Israeli embassy.<ref name="Protests held in Ireland over Israeli attack">{{cite news |author1=Burke-Kennedy, Eoin |author2=Newenham, Pamela |lastauthoramp=yes |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0531/breaking21.html|title=Protests held in Ireland over Israeli attack|date=31 May 2010 |work=[[The Irish Times]] |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> Those present at the Dublin protest included [[Aengus Ó Snodaigh]] and [[Chris Andrews (politician)|Chris Andrews]], both of whom Cypriot authorities had prevented from joining the flotilla, as well as [[Lord Mayor of Dublin]] [[Emer Costello]].<ref name="Protests held in Ireland over Israeli attack"/> Palestinians supporters of both Hamas and Fatah were part of the protests, with chants mostly in Arabic.<ref>[http://www.indymedia.ie/article/90363 "Irish Protests Against Israeli Attacks on Gaza Escalate"] – Indymedia Ireland.</ref>
During 1–5 June, thousands of people rallied throughout various cities across the United States and Canada to protest the flotilla raid and the subsequent seizure of the [[MV Rachel Corrie]] and its crew, including Chicago, San Francisco, Los Angeles, [[Minneapolis]], Minnesota, [[Toronto]], [[Ottawa]], [[Montreal]] and [[Vancouver]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wsws.org/articles/2010/jun2010/demo-j03.shtml |title=3, June, 2010 |publisher=[[World Socialist Web Site]] |date=3 June 2010 |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Chapin Gray |url=http://www.fightbacknews.org/2010/6/3/thousands-protest-chicago-against-israeli-attack-gaza-freedom-flotilla |title=Thousands protest in Chicago against Israeli attack on Gaza 2010 |publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |accessdate=1 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/meast/05/31/israel.gaza.protests/index.html|title=Israeli raid met with |location=Melbourne, Australia |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref>
On 4 June, there were protests in Ireland and Malaysia. The Israeli embassy in [[Dublin]] was blockaded by dozens of people, causing its closure for the day but authorities deemed it a peaceful protest and no arrests were made.<ref>{{cite news |author=Carroll, Steven|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0604/breaking25.html|title=Protest continues at Israeli embassy|date=4 June 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]] |accessdate=4 June 2010}}</ref> Opposition leader [[Anwar Ibrahim]] was among protesters who gathered outside the US embassy along [[Jalan Tun Razak]] in [[Kuala Lumpur]], disrupting traffic for several hours.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Sira Habibu |author2=Steven Chiew |lastauthoramp=yes |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2010/6/4/nation/20100604143049&sec=nation |title=Groups protest in front of US embassy over Israeli raid (Update) |date=4 June 2010 |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |accessdate=4 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605140002/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2010%2F6%2F4%2Fnation%2F20100604143049&sec=nation |archivedate=5 June 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On 5 June further demonstrations were organised in the United Kingdom, with the Scottish Palestine Solidarity Campaign leading a three-thousand strong march in Edinburgh.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/10246953.stm|title=Thousands join Gaza protest in Edinburgh|date=5 June 2010 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=5 June 2010}}</ref> In London thousands marched from Downing Street to the Israeli embassy to express their outrage at Israeli actions.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article7144702.ece|title=Thousands protest flotilla killings in London and Istanbul|date=5 June 2010 |work=[[The Times]] |accessdate=5 June 2010}}</ref>
On 7 June 2010, approximately 200 mostly Muslim students threw stones at a group of Israelis while chanting "Murderers", and subsequently broke the window of the police car that they took refuge in. One of the Israelis was injured. The incident occurred at the start of the Spain-Israel Chamber of Commerce's conference at Madrid's Autonomous University. Following the violence, the university called off the conference due to safety concerns.<ref>[http://www.jta.org/news/article/2010/06/08/2739502/madrid-protesters-attack-israeli-businessmen "Madrid protesters attack Israeli businessmen"], [[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]] (JTA), 8 June 2010.</ref> According to Spanish media, the organizers had changed the conference's venue at the last minute due to concerns about potential violence but the protestors discovered the new location and stormed in while chanting, "Murderers, murderers. Get out of Gaza" and "Freedom to the Palestinian people".<ref>Aviel Magnezi, [http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3902046,00.html "Spain: Pro-Palestinian activists attack Israeli businessmen"] [[Ynetnews]], 8 June 2010.</ref>
===Support=== [[File:Tel Aviv university students support Israel against Gaza Flotilla.jpg|thumb|250px|A demonstration of [[Tel Aviv University]] students supporting Israel and [[Shayetet 13]] against the Gaza Flotilla 2010]] Many pro-Israeli rallies took place within the country, including by [[Sderot]] residents, in [[Qiryat Shmona]] and student rallies in the [[Technion]], [[University of Haifa]], [[Ben Gurion University]], [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] and [[Tel Aviv University]]. The rallies included hundreds of demonstrators waving the [[flag of Israel]] and chanting slogans in support of the [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] and [[Shayetet 13]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.israelhayom.co.il/site/newsletter_article.php?a=6792 |title=התומכים והמוחים |language=he |trans-title=Supporters and protesters |date=2 June 2010 |author=Yuri Yalon |author2=Daniel Sirioti, |author3=Efrat Forsher |author4=Gadi Golan |newspaper=[[Israel Hayom]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.local.co.il/haifa/70790/article.htm |title=הסתבכות בלב הים: הפגנת תמיכה בחיילי צה"ל בקריות |language=he |trans-title=Entanglement at sea: Demonstration of IDF soldiers in Haifa suburbs |date=31 May 2010 |author=Michael Frosmoskin |publisher=local.co.il}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.walla.co.il/item/1681223 |title=אלפים הפגינו בתל אביב בעד ונגד פעילות צה"ל |language=he |trans-title=Thousands rally in Tel Aviv for and against IDF operations |date=31 May 2010 |publisher=Walla!}}</ref> A large and fierce protest was held in front of the Turkish embassy, which included slogans such as "Shayetet 13, we are with you," "We are all the IDF," "Cold weapons kill." Protesters also accused Turkish Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] of "supporting terrorism" and equated him with [[Osama Bin-Laden]] and [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]].<ref>{{cite news |author=Yuval Golan |url=http://www.nrg.co.il/online/1/ART2/116/067.html |title=הפגנה מול שגרירות טורקיה: "כולנו צה"ל" |trans-title=Protest was held in front of Turkey embassy: "We are all the IDF" |language=Hebrew |date=3 June 2010 |newspaper=[[Maariv (newspaper)|Maariv]]}}</ref> They also chanted, "The [Gaza] flotilla is burning," while carrying signs reading, "Ahmadinejad=Erdogan". The organizers of the embassy protest described themselves as young [[zionist]]s.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3896989,00.html |title=Dozens at Turkish embassy: Erdogan like Ahmadinejad|publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=20 June 1995 |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/Flash.aspx/187228 |title=News Briefs |publisher=[[Arutz Sheva]] |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref>
In Los Angeles about 1000 demonstrators were protesting in front of the Turkish Consulate on 1 June in support of Israel.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/06/protest-at-turkish-consulate-.html |title=Hundreds rally in support of Israeli raid on flotilla at L.A. Turkish Consulate |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] blogs |location=India|date= 1 June 2010|accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> A Jewish high school student was seen walking through a crowd of anti-Israeli protesters alone, carrying a large Israeli flag. Police officers feared for his safety, and escorted him to protect him from potential attacks.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/JewishWorld/JewishNews/Article.aspx?id=177298 |title=In Los Angeles, Daniel enters the lion's den |newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |accessdate=4 June 2010}}</ref> On 6 June, demonstrators rallied to show solidarity with Israel at the Israeli consulate in Los Angeles. Notable attendees included Governor [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]], Republican gubernatorial candidate [[Steve Poizner]], actor [[Jon Voight]], Republican Senate contender [[Chuck DeVore]], Representative [[Brad Sherman]] and Rabbi [[Marvin Hier]] of the [[Simon Wiesenthal Center]], Los Angeles City Controller [[Wendy Greuel]], City Council members [[Paul Koretz]] and [[Janice Hahn]], [[Judea Pearl]], and David Pine of [[Americans for Peace Now]]. Several Christian groups were also represented.<ref>Zavis, Alexandra. (6 June 2010) [http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-israel-rally-20100607,0,5661358.story Israel supporters rally in L.A. after raid on Gaza-bound flotilla]. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''.</ref> In New York City, a number of pro-Israel Jews gathered to show their support for Israel.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbn.com/cbnnews/insideisrael/2010/June/Israels-Flotilla-Raid-Sparks-Demonstrations-in-NYC-/ |title=Israel's Flotilla Raid Sparks Demonstrations in NYC |publisher=[[Christian Broadcasting Network]] |accessdate=4 June 2010}}</ref> While in [[Baltimore]] a pro-Israel rally, organized by the Baltimore Zionist District sough to raise awareness of what supporters called an act of self-defense by Israel against [[Hamas]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/bs-md-baltimore-zionist-district-20100604,0,1087754.story |title=Pro-Israeli demonstrators rally downtown |newspaper=[[The Baltimore Sun]] |accessdate=5 June 2010}}</ref> As many as 600 people gathered on 6 June at the [[Torch of Friendship]] in downtown Miami's [[Bayfront Park]]. North Miami Beach City Council member Frantz Pierre led the crowd in a chant of "Peace, peace, peace". Jewish and Christian religious leaders were present. Mohammad S. Shakir, a Muslim and director of the Asian American Advisory Board in the [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade County]] Office of Community Advocacy, made a speech.<ref name="miamiherald.com"/>
On 2 June, in London the [[Zionist Federation of Great Britain and Ireland]] organized a pro-Israel rally in front of Israeli embassy.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3898300,00.html/ |title=Hundreds at pro-Israel rally in London |publisher=[[Ynetnews]]|accessdate=4 June 2010}}</ref> On 4 June, a demonstration was held in [[Vienna]]. On 6 June an event in support Israel in Paris was cancelled due to threats from pro-Palestinian groups. On 6 June, a rally was held in [[Brussels]].<ref name="jpost.com"/>
The [[National Union of Israeli Students]] planned to send a Kurdish Freedom Flotilla. According to Boaz Torporovsky, President of the Student Union, the plan is to send a flotilla of ships "to deliver much-needed humanitarian assistance to the [[Kurds]] of Turkey".<ref name="Selig">{{cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel/Article.aspx?id=177789|title=Ideas for ‘Reverse Flotillas’ Gain Steam|last=Selig|first=Abe|date=8 June 2010|work=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|accessdate=28 June 2010}}</ref>
Israeli Arab members of the [[Knesset]], Israel's parliament, received numerous death threats after the incident.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]|last=Cook|first=Jonathan|title=Israeli Arab MPs receive death threats over aid flotilla|date=15 June 2010|url=http://www.thenational.ae/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100616/FOREIGN/706159884/1135|accessdate=16 June 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929055050/http://www.thenational.ae/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20100616%2FFOREIGN%2F706159884%2F1135|archivedate=29 September 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> A bus driver hired by the Israeli military to transport soldiers put up a sign on the bus saying: "Shayetet 13, shame on you. Why did you kill so few?"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3903747,00.html |title=IDF-hired driver: 'Why did they kill so few?' |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=20 June 1995 |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref>
===Polls===
A [[Rasmussen Reports]] national telephone poll in the United States of 1000 voters found that 49% of respondents blame pro-Palestinian activists on the Gaza bound aid ships for the deaths that resulted. 19% blamed Israel and 32% were not sure. 51% of those polled thought that Israel should allow an international investigation into the incident, while 25% agreed with Israel's refusal.<ref>[http://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/politics/current_events/israel_the_middle_east/49_say_pro_palestinian_activists_to_blame_in_gaza_ship_incident "49% Say Pro-Palestinian Activists To Blame in Gaza Ship Incident"] – [[Rasmussen Reports]] (7 June 2010).</ref>
A [[Yougov]] survey found that 55% of the Britons polled believed Israel had overreacted, 27% didn't know and 18% thought they'd acted in self-defence. When asked about an international investigation, an overwhelming 74% believed it should be conducted by an international group. 4% thought it should be led by Israel, 12% didn't know, and 11% thought an inquiry shouldn't be held as it was a distraction from peace negotiations.<ref>[http://www.today.yougov.co.uk/sites/today.yougov.co.uk/files/YG-Archives-Pol-Sun-Israel-010610.pdf "Survey Report"]. (PDF). {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5qcUV0crk?url=http://www.today.yougov.co.uk/sites/today.yougov.co.uk/files/YG-Archives-Pol-Sun-Israel-010610.pdf |date=20 June 2010 }}</ref>
=== Flotilla movement ===
Jewish Voices for a Just Peace, a group of German Jews belonging to the [[European Jews for a Just Peace]] that plans to send a boat with humanitarian aid to break the Gaza blockade, has received a large number of request to travel with the ship, and is searching for a second vessel to accommodate additional participants.<ref name="German Jews Inundated"/>
==Others== In Ireland, [[Lord Mayor of Cork]] [[Dara Murphy]] opened a book of condolence.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/martin-demands-entry-to-gaza-for-irish-aid-ship-2203056.html |title=Martin demands entry to Gaza for Irish aid ship |work=[[Irish Independent]] |date=1 June 2010 |accessdate=1 June 2010}}</ref>
Four trucks carrying tents, blankets and 13 power generators were donated by Russia and Oman.<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5ioi_0jtO9RjMwPNRoXNCndRPRq3gD9G31JJG0 "Gazans cross border after Egypt lifts blockade"]. [[Associated Press]]. (2 June 2010). {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605161929/http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5ioi_0jtO9RjMwPNRoXNCndRPRq3gD9G31JJG0 |date= 5 June 2010 }}</ref>
==Result of international actions==<!--could move this to the main page-->
===United Nations Security Council=== The [[United Nations Security Council]] convened an emergency meeting at the request of Turkey, during which the [[Ahmet Davutoglu|Turkish foreign minister]] stated "Israel must be held accountable for its crimes" (prior to the meeting, the [[Riyad Mansour|Palestinian ambassador to the UN]] called for an independent Security Council investigation). While the [[Mark Lyall Grant|British ambassador]] said Israel should end the Gaza blockade and take steps for an investigation, the [[Alejandro Wolff|US deputy permanent representative]] supported the Israeli position that humanitarian aid should have gone by "accepted international mechanisms", and the [[Daniel Carmon|Israeli deputy permanent representative]] said the flotilla was not humanitarian but had a mission of breaking the blockade.<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/meast/05/31/un.security.council.gaza/index.html?hpt=T1 "U.N. Security Council meets on Israeli raid"] 1 June 2010, [[CNN]].</ref><!--also said some were terrorists on board, can include that in the israeli response-->
The United States directly intervened to prevent the [[United Nations Security Council]]'s statement, which requested an "impartial" investigation of the deaths and condemned those "acts" that led to it, from resembling that drafted by Turkey, the Palestinians and Arab states, which called for condemnation "in the strongest terms" and an independent international inquiry.<ref name="Turkey demands Israel be 'punished' over Gaza raid">{{cite news|author1=Naughton, Philippe |author2=Evans, Judith |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Turkey demands Israel be 'punished' over Gaza raid|newspaper=[[The Times]]|date=1 June 2010|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article7141783.ece | location=London}}</ref> 12 hours of negotiations were required to come up with a statement that suited all.<ref name="Turkey demands Israel be 'punished' over Gaza raid"/>
As a result of the emergency meeting that went into the early hours of the morning, the council agreed condemn the acts that resulted in the deaths and injuries aboard the ''Mavi Marmara''. They also called for a prompt, impartial, credible and transparent investigation conforming to international standards. This was different from what Turkey and the Arab states were demanded – an independent international investigation—leaving open the possibility of who would conduct the investigation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/europe/UN-Security-Council-Calls-for-Impartial-Credible-Investigation-of-Israeli-Boat-Raid-95297034.html |title=UN Security Council Calls for Impartial, Credible Investigation of Israeli Boat Raid |publisher=[[Voice of America News]] |date=20 August 2009 |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref><ref name=USAT>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2010-06-01-un-israel-censure_N.htm |title=U.N. condemns Israeli flotilla raid, calls for investigation |work=[[USA Today]] |date=1 June 2010 |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref><ref name=NYTUNSC>[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/02/world/middleeast/02nations.html "U.N. Security Council Condemns 'Acts' in Israeli Raid"], ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref><ref name=UNSCGuardian>{{cite news|author1=Harriet Sherwood in Ashdod |author2=Matthew Weaver |lastauthoramp=yes |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jun/01/un-condemns-israel-assault-gaza-flotilla |title=UN calls for inquiry into Israel flotilla attack |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |date=1 June 2010 |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref>
===United Nations Human Rights Council=== The [[United Nations Human Rights Council]] passed a resolution by 32 votes to 3, with a number of abstentions, in which it condemned in the strongest terms the outrageous attack by the Israeli forces that resulted in the killing and injuring of many innocent civilians from different countries, and decided to dispatch an independent international fact finding mission to investigate violations of international law resulting from the Israeli attack.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=10095&LangID=E |title=UN Human Rights Council decides to dispatch independant<!--SIC--> fact finding mission; English |publisher=[[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]] |date=2 June 2010 |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/e18d2a8a-6e23-11df-ab79-00144feabdc0.html |title=UN council votes for international inquiry |work=[[Financial Times]] |date=2 June 2010 |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref>
